abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Transport Sector
            Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, a broad sector-wide investment operation, in
            this case a transport sector project covering roads, ports,
            airports, and overall sector planning and coordination, is
            an effective instrument for improving the efficiency of
            transport services and increasing their supply throughout
            the country. Second, the country team should help ensure
            that generic country issues, such as counterpart funding,
            are dealt with in a uniform fashion across the board. Third,
            addressing sector specific issues through projects is
            impossible without real political will. Finally, project
            content should be designed to match actual project
            management competencies, and the management tools
            implemented by foreign technical assistance should be fully
            internalized by users within the existing and sustainable
            institutional framework.
